explanation:
OS_ErrorTable_Entry_t - needed to know the types/qualifiers of .Name and .Number (e.g. whether they are volatile, typedefs, or have side-effecting accessors). This determines whether the loop condition (Error->Name != NULL && Error->Number != error_num) has persistent side effects or uses objects modified in the loop body.
OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE - needed to know the object Error is initially pointed into (array vs function-returned pointer, constness, storage) to determine whether pointer increments (++Error) or reads from Error affect other objects or have side effects.
OS_IMPL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE - same reason as OS_GLOBAL_ERROR_NAME_TABLE for the second search loop.
os_err_name_t - required to interpret expressions using err_name, sizeof(*err_name) and indexing operations to check for unintended side effects or misuses that could relate to loop-control analysis (and to confirm pointer/array semantics used later in the function).
OS_CHECK_POINTER - macro/function may expand to code containing loops, early returns or side effects; its definition is needed to ensure it does not introduce for-loops or modify objects used in subsequent loop conditions.
OS_ERROR_NAME_LENGTH - used in bounds and sizing expressions (sizeof usage and final truncation). Needed to validate sizeof(*err_name) expressions and to check whether the code after the loops affects objects used in the loop control.
OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR - return codes used after the loops; included to fully understand control-flow/early-exit semantics in the function (ensure no hidden control-flow that interacts with loop behavior).
strncpy - standard library function used after the loops; include to confirm it has no unexpected side effects on objects used as loop counters/controls.
snprintf - standard library function used after the loops; include for the same reason as strncpy.

Note: The MISRA item concerns the well-formedness of for-loops. The target function uses while-loops; nonetheless the above symbols are necessary to confirm that the loop conditions have no persistent side effects, that the pointer increment (++Error) only modifies the local loop pointer, and that no macro or called routine (e.g. OS_CHECK_POINTER) injects a for-loop or modifies objects used in loop control.
